column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing the human resources management (HRM) course, students:

column5: Understand the difference between best practice and best fit HRM strategies.
Can explain how HRM in general, and individual HR practices in specific, contribute to organizational performance.
Can explain the impact of organizational strategy on HRM practices and choices.
Can explain and apply the various steps during the recruitment and selection phase, and make informed decisions on (evidence based) recruitment and selection techniques.
Understand and use the concept of competency and related concepts.
Explain the Five Factor Model (FFM) of personality, sometimes referred to as the Big5.
Understand the key elements that make experiences developmental, and use this understanding to improve organizational practices in order to facilitate learning and development.
Understand how employment relationships are changing (in terms of expectations towards one and another) and how this affects the role of learning and development.
Will be acquainted with various motivation theories, and understand how managers and organizations can use these theories in practice.
Understand the basic building blocks of performance management.

column3: After completing the Information and Communication Technology (ICT) course, students will be able to:

column5: Understand the use and value of IT in relationship to organization strategy.
Understand how IT can be implemented in organizations
Be able to identify the important aspects that have to be dealt with when implementing ICT solutions
Understand the main features and principles of an IT architecture and relate them to business needs and priorities.
Understand and explain the use of different types of large scale backoffice systems like ERP/CRM in organizations
Make a structured, motivated analysis of the use of IT in an organization
Understand and use/apply the 4 different types of IT and business Alignment as described by Henderson & Venkatraman
Explain how IT can function as a driver or enabler for organizations.
Understand and use/apply IT governance rules as described by Raines (“Raines Rules”)
Make a first-cut motivated risk analysis of a large IT project, using Boonstra’s inventory of project risks

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Future forward has 2 separate parts: Human resources management (HRM), and Information and Communication Technology (ICT).
HRM focuses upon how HRM-policies and practices contribute to organizational performance.

column5: Lectures, tutorials
Final exam (100%)

column3: ICT for Business focuses upon the use and value of IT in relationship to organization strategy, and the important aspects that have to be dealt with when implementing ICT solutions. Each of the courses will make up 50% of the total grade.

column5: Lectures, tutorials
Group paper and presentation (100%)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172433,2016,Business and Society,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After a year of analysing and applying business concepts, this short course zooms in on strategies how you can use your business knowledge and competences to have a stronger impact on society. Elements to be covered include business ethics, corporate social responsibility, social innovation, and public affairs. In a series of workshops that introduce a case study setting, you are asked to dig deeper into each of those elements. In addition, the course is congruent to your master thesis in that it asks you to reflect on the real world perspective of your research and helps you to reflect on that in the thesis itself.

column2: • To provide a deeper understanding of the societal roles & implications of business development & entrepreneurship
• To apply the accumulated knowledge by reflecting on your research and by integrating elements in your plans for your professional career

• One personal reflection case, related to intro motivational interview at start of the Master programme (what have been your expectations on this master at the start, what have you learnt, how will/can you apply this in your professional career in the coming five years, etc.)
• Evaluation of reports of plenary cases (group, 50%) + participation in discussion (individual, 10%)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173093,2016,Business and Sustainability Challenges,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. S.O. Negro'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The objective of this course is to introduce the students to the sustainability challenges and discourses and the role that companies are playing in this (whether impacting negatively or positively).
After completion of the course, the student is able to:

column5: understand the global sustainability challenges;
evaluate the major sustainability oriented alternatives (technological, managerial, and organisational);
evaluate the importance of systems and life cycle thinking;
evaluate the role and impacts that businesses have on the environment and societies (positive and negative);
evaluate how businesses can influence the context they are operating in, and vice versa how the context pressurises the businesses to act/change in a sustainable way.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Sustainability has grown into a societal paradigm that cannot be ignored by firms.  Consumers, citizens, NGOs and policy makers clearly express the demand that firms innovate and do business in a way that is socially responsible.  Firms know that they need to deal with this growing societal demand but struggle in their efforts realizing this. Path dependencies, lack of knowledge and internal resistance to change make change difficult.  This course, therefore, offers preliminary insight in sustainability challenges, technological  options that can be used by firms to produce in a more environmental friendly manner and social science knowledge that creates insight in the behavior of organizations, stakeholders involved and organizational change and innovation.

Through lectures and guest lectures by experts and businesses we will discuss the global challenges and how they affect firms to change their practices. What kind of strategies do they have to change their practices within the firm?  What kind of strategies do they have to change the context in which they operate? Which kind of technological options can they apply to achieve the change?
Concepts that will be treated in this course are:

column5: Sustainable development and sustainability discourses
Systems thinking
Life cycle thinking
Corporate Sustainability (focusing on the role of businesses in contributing to sustainable development)

column3: The challenges that will discussed and presented by experts will be about Climate Change, Energy, Water, Food and Health.
This course is an entry requirement for:

column5: Consultancy Project SBI (GEO4-2605)
Master’s Thesis Internship (GEO4-2606)

column3: Academic skills: Concise writing, valuing literature, giving feedback

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173996,2016,Business intelligence,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. M.R. Spruit'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: At the end of the course, students should be able to:

column5: Understand the fundamentals of the collection of technologies called Business Intelligence (BI)
Understand the relationships between BI technologies within a typical BI architecture
Relate the theoretical foundations to professional experiences in daily practice
Experience the typical steps performed in a BI implementation project
Obtain hands-on experience with professional BI tooling
Understand current state-of-the-art research in BI technologies

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course deals with a collection of computer technologies that support managerial decision making by providing information of both internal and external aspects of operations. They have had a profound impact on corporate strategy, performance, and competitiveness, and are collectively known as business intelligence.
During this course the following BI topics will be covered:

column5: Business perspective
Statistics
Data management
Data integration
Data warehousing
Data mining
Reporting and online analytic processing (i.e., descriptive analytics)
Quantitative analysis and operations research (i.e., predictive analytics)
Management communications (written and oral)
Systems analysis and design
Software development

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172776,2016,Business, Sustainability and Innovation",English,Faculty of Geosciences,,[],,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course the student will be able to:

column5: understand a range of concepts, tools, and techniques available to companies to better contribute to sustainability;
be able to recognise and describe the different tools and initiatives being taken by companies to contribute to sustainability;
reflect critically about the implementation of the concepts and tools;
take a holistic and long-term perspective of sustainability tools and initiatives; and
provide recommendations about the concepts and tools to a real case study.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Introduction to corporate social responsibility and corporate sustainability (including the UN Global compact, and discussion about differences of the concepts);
Systems thinking (including a brief discussion on stakeholders) and life cycle thinking (with a brief discussion on LCA);
Innovation strategies for corporate sustainability;
Industrial ecology;
Design for environment and cleaner chemistry;
Eco-efficiency and cleaner production;
Environmental Management Systems;
Sustainability assessment and communication;
Organisational change management for sustainability;
Sustainability supply chain (green purchasing and green marketing); and
Sustainability and socially responsible investment.

column3: The theoretical part contains an exam in week 6. It is essential to master the information provided in the theoretical part, to be able to participate fully in the practical part that commences after week 4.
In the empirical part of the course students will, in small groups, analyse a real-life case study’s contributions to sustainability.
The groups will write a report on the case study and present it.
The first part of the course will take place in the classroom, while for the second part, the students will mostly engage with the case study.
It is highly advised not to take  more than 1 other course besides this one in this period.
This course is an entry requirement for: Bachelor’s thesis MMW (GEO3-2137) (thema Duurzaam Ondernemen)

Academic skills: creative problem solving, project management, teamwork, communication with clients, presentation in English, critical thinking, data collection and analysis, written report writing in English.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171115,2016,CASTOR03 Power, politics and the state: Anthropological perspectives",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. C. Grasseni'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Advanced knowledge of the principal theoretical debates in anthropology and adjoining disciplines about state, power and politics.

column5: In-depth knowledge of contemporary theories about the relationships between power, politics, and the state, with reference to notions such as: governmentality, cultural intimacy, transnationalism, neoliberalism, audit cultures, regimes of care.
Awareness of the methodological consequences of current theoretical debates for empirical research.
Reflection on the relation between theory and data.
Development of oral presentation skills through the chairing of seminar discussion.
Development of academic writing and research skills through an essay, a book review, and a research paper about an ethnographic topic concerning power, politics and the state.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course examines three interconnected key concepts in the social sciences: power, politics and the state. It will provide the theoretical and methodological tools necessary for understanding them in a distinctly anthropological manner, namely by giving ethnographic attention to systems of meaning and belief, agency, everyday practice, the hidden and overt mechanics of power. The course analyzes governance, governmentality and processes of state-making from the vantage point of societal actors. This perspective demonstrates that states are fragmented and face a multitude of social organizations, such as political parties, companies, social interest groups, and ethnic groups that maintain and vie for power.

Structures of domination, hierarchy and negotiation combine violence and coercion, as well as consent and legitimacy, in mutually constitutive processes of state-making and societal change. The course will pay attention to how state structures, power and authority are constantly challenged, resisted and transformed, often involving conflict, compromise and illegalities. The examination of the practices and symbols of everyday state-making (for example in bureaucracy) will reveal the mythologies and discourses of the state as a source of social order.
Schedule: An effort is made to schedule seminars on Mondays afternoons. For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual.
Course Attendance: Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:

column5: 80% attendance (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and
Mandatory participation in seminars. Overdue papers are downgraded with a one point per day penalty.

column3: There exists no collective possibility to resubmit rewritten papers. Only students who have complied with all commitment policy requirements will be given one additional chance to submit a rewritten paper within three weeks after the end of the course. Resubmission is not a right of students but a privilege given by the course coordinator on a case-to-case basis, and therefore requires her permission.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171040,2016,MCASTOR05 Ethnographic Methods and Research Design,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. G.A. Steenbeek', 'dr. G.L.A.M. Mommersteeg']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Advanced knowledge of the principal methodologies of ethnographic research.
Developing the competence of independently carrying out ethnographic field research.
Critical reflection on the epistemic status of field research.
Advanced training in structured, semi-structured and open interview techniques.
Thorough understanding of the epistemological and methodological implications of interviews.
In-depth knowledge of range of interview strategies.
Reflection on the relation between questions and data.
Development of conversational skills in interviews.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Fieldwork is the defining research strategy of anthropology and demands solid preparation. This course is devoted to the practicalities of actually ‘doing’ ethnographic fieldwork in real world settings. The course is dedicated to an understanding of the practice of fieldwork methods, in particular participant observation, ethnographic interviewing, and writing and processing ethnographic field notes. Participant observation is dealt with not so much as a formal method but as a way to gather contextual information that can help in the recognition of topics for investigation, to help identify potential informants for subsequent interviewing, and to build rapport in the fieldwork setting. Further, students are taught how to classify and organize their field notes, turn observations into ethnographic data, and pay close attention to gaps in their local knowledge. The importance and complexity of language usage is also investigated by emphasizing how the social relationship between researcher and research subject shapes inter-personal communication.

Part of a solid preparation also includes the development of research skills. The scientific knowledge about people's lives, decisions, interactions, cultural models, and practices is acquired to an important degree through verbal communication. Conversations, dialogues and interviews are complex speech forms which require a thorough understanding of the social interaction among the interlocutors. Students will undergo an intensive master class in qualitative interviewing. During three weeks students will develop interviewing proficiency, an essential skill considering that the majority of ethnographic data is generated through both formal and informal conversations. A range of interviewing strategies are introduced and critically assessed, including unstructured interviewing, semi-structured interviewing, and structured interviewing. Students are trained through recording of their own exercises and post-interview evaluations. Technical aspects of interviewing such as recording and transcribing are dealt with as well.

At the same time, the course will guide students in writing their research proposal. They will complete drafts of their proposals by the end of the course in consultation with their thesis advisors with whom they will have weekly meetings.
For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual. Note that the schedule of the interview masterclass is intensive (3 to 4 days a week).
Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:

column5: 80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and
Obligatory participation in seminars.

column4: There exists no collective possibility to resubmit rewritten papers. Only students who have complied with all commitment policy requirements will be given one additional chance to submit a rewritten paper within three weeks after the course ended. Resubmission is not a right of students but a privilege given by the course coordinator on a case-to-case basis, and therefore require his permission.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170996,2016,CASTOR06: Political Conflict and Social Trauma,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. A.C.G.M. Robben', 'prof. dr. I.H. Komproe']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Advanced knowledge of the principal contemporary theoretical debates about violence, political conflict, trauma, and social suffering

column5: In-depth examination of recent theories about political conflict at the interpersonal and community level, and their relation to violence and social suffering.
Understanding political violence and social suffering as multidimensional processes instead of unicausal events.
Conducting a multi-level anthropological analysis.
Development of oral presentation skills and the chairing of seminar discussion.
The development of academic writing and research skills through one major research assignment about a violent conflict.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: How are ordinary people affected by large crises, such as wars, epidemics, and natural disasters? What are the connections between these two different levels of social complexity?

This course examines the relation between political conflicts occurring on the national or international level, and the suffering of individuals, families and local communities. Social suffering is an anthropological concept that provides an understanding of the sociopolitical forces that impact on people, and reveals how they respond to those devastating influences in their daily lives. It brings together multiple social, economic, political, and cultural dimensions that impinge on people, families, and communities, and draws attention to empathy as an epistemological approach to social reality. Empathy implicates researchers and research subjects in the production of ethnographic knowledge, and yields an insider perspective comparable to participant observation.
For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual.
Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:

column5: 80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and
Obligatory participation in seminars.

column3: There exists no collective possibility to resubmit rewritten papers. Only students who have complied with all commitment policy requirements will be given one additional chance to submit a rewritten paper within three weeks after the course ended. C. Grasseni', 'dr. F.I. Jara Gomez', 'dr. J.G. de Kruijf', 'dr. M. Oosterbaan', 'prof. dr. A.C.G.M. Robben', 'prof. dr. C.G. Koonings']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Advanced knowledge of the principal ethnographic studies about the field area
In-depth knowledge of the principal anthropological debates about the field area
Ethnographic elaboration of key terms, such as culture, agency, power, practice, meaning and flows, in field area
Awareness of  the political and ethical circumstances of conducting fieldwork in the field area
Reflection on the relation between theory and data
Development of oral debating skills
Development of academic writing and research skills through one critical essay and the preparation of an extensive bibliography
Write the a large definitive version of the research plan, including a theoretical and methodological framework and a short version for approval by the Board of Studies

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course consists of intensive tutorials in which individual students team up with individual staff members from the Department of Cultural Anthropology to acquire a thorough knowledge of the principal anthropological literature and key studies from history and political science about the student’s proposed fieldwork area. Students are taught how to determine the reliability of their bibliographic sources, how to identify the crucial texts in the vast number of available studies about the chosen area, and how to design a bibliography geared to the conceptual research needs. Additionally the students work on the long  version of their research proposal, which they complete using the extended knowledge of the fieldwork area. The long research proposal integrates the theoretical and methodological framework with the key studies on the fieldwork location.

column5: 80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and Obligatory participation in seminars.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171215,2016,CASTOR08 Ethnicity and religion under globalization,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. M. Oosterbaan'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Advanced knowledge of the principal contemporary theoretical debates about     religion,     ethnicity,     and     globalization.
Understanding religious and ethnic aspirations as multidimensional         processes         instead         of         unicausal         events.
Development of oral presentation skills and the chairing of seminar         discussion.
The development of academic writing and research skills through one         major         research         assignment.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course explores the social and cultural transformations in contemporary processes of globalization that have brought about a greater salience of the issues of ethnicity and religion. A key focus will be the globalization of the Western concept of religion as a sphere of life separate from politics, economy and law, and the resulting consequences of the encounter of Western understandings of religion with religious traditions in other parts of the world. We will examine how such traditions have been compelled to reinvent and to reposition themselves in light of modern concepts of religion. Another parallel development is the spread of Western notions of nationhood and ethnicity, which has also led to profound transformation of political and social difference in the non-Western world. The intersection of the spread of modern religion and Herderian notions of ethnicity coupled to the principle of political self-determination will be the main topic of the other half of the course. An important question to be addressed is whether and how colonialism and contemporary processes of globalization have had different impacts on ethnic and religious identities. Case studies will include religious reform and ethnicity in Africa, where the colonial spread of modern 'religion' and ethno-nationality is nowadays further reinforced by religious and ethnic mobilization through media and transnational religious networks under conditions of globalization. We will also discuss case studies of Christian evangelism in Africa and Brazil, where a combination of colonial legacies and contemporary media-driven globalization have resulted in new types of religious and ethnic identities.  Schedule: For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual.  Commitment: Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:

column5: 80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and
Obligatory participation in seminars.

column3: There exists no collective possibility to resubmit rewritten papers. Only students who have complied with all commitment policy requirements will be given one additional chance to submit a rewritten paper within three weeks after the course ended. Resubmission is not a right of students but a privilege given by the course coordinator on a case-to-case basis, and therefore require his permission.

column5: Advanced knowledge of the intersection of ethnographic research with theory building
Developing the competence of theoretical reflection on fieldwork data
Critical reflection on the epistemic status of field research
Critical reflection on the challenges contemporary transnational and highly mediatized field settings pose not only to ethnography but also theory formation

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After students have completed their fieldwork, the main task that needs to go hand-in-hand with writing is the combination of such first-hand research with secondary data (historical, socio-economic, media-based, environmental, legal, etc.), and finally with the larger, more general theoretical questions students set out to answer or the theoretical debate they are addressing. This practical seminar initiates the writing of the M.Sc. thesis, and teaches students how to use their empirical knowledge and secondary materials to develop broader interpretations about their study in a meaningful relationship with the theoretical frame of their research question.

column4: The course covers the essentials of qualitative research, in particular techniques for identifying themes, the making of systematic comparisons, and grounding interpretation in theory. Finally, it focuses on the principles of dovetailing primary ethnographic research, secondary data, and larger theoretical frames.
For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual.

column3: This seminar teaches students how to improve the structure, narrative, clarity, and style of writing, while addressing problems such as writer's block and bibliographic overload. It allows students to build up the confidence that they have significant research data which need to be reported in a scientific style to allow them to communicate with the academic community. The seminar provides students with a biweekly forum to discuss and demonstrate their progress in writing their M.Sc. theses. Students will distribute drafts in advance to allow two discussants to make extensive comments, and make students benefit from the input of peers and instructors to write a high-quality thesis.
An effort is made to schedule seminars on Thurdays. For a biweekly class schedule, please consult the course manual.
Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:

column3: The master thesis completes the empirical research cycle and constitutes the final test of the student's academic skills, theoretical, conceptual and anthropological knowledge, ethical responsibility, methodological training, and ethnographic research capabilities. The thesis exemplifies the integration of learning and research, and attests to the student's academic advancement in knowledge and skills. The M.Sc. thesis has a maximum length of 15,000 words (including notes and bibliography, excluding abstract and summary), and includes an introduction, ethnographic substantiation, a conclusion, a bibliography, a scientific abstract (250 words) and a general summary (500 words). The thesis begins with an abstract followed by an introduction with a discussion of the main research question, a discussion the theoretical perspective and relevant anthropological debate, and an explanation of the research methodology and chosen field methods. The substantive ethnographic part is a detailed presentation and analysis of the empirical data. The conclusion summarizes the principal research findings, addresses the research question, and formulates a theoretically grounded statement about future research lines. The thesis ends with a summary intended for a general public. Schedule To be arranged with the thesis supervisor. Commitment Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of::

column4: Na afloop van de cursus kan de student in samenwerking met medestudenten:
-       een onderzoeksvraag bedenken en verbinden met een maatschappelijk thema.
-       methoden en technieken  van de Communicatie- en informatiewetenschap inzetten en de
-       gegevens verzamelen en deze analyseren en interpreteren.
-       conclusies trekken uit analyses met aandacht voor de complementariteit van de gegevens.
-       de opzet, uitvoering, resultaten en conclusies helder verwoorden.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De studenten voeren onder leiding van een docent een onderzoek uit naar een massamediale (overheids)campagne. Daarbij gaat het er in de eerste plaats om inzicht te krijgen in hoe de campagne “werkt”. Oftewel: op welke manieren worden taal, beeld en media ingezet om de campagnedoelen te realiseren. Daarnaast is het de bedoeling dat je tot een evaluatief oordeel komt over de campagne, onder meer door empirisch onderzoek te doen, maar ook door de campagne kritisch te beschouwen vanuit een ideologie.  De studenten mogen ook zelf een organisatie aandragen als 'opdrachtgever' van hun onderzoek. De opzet van het eigen onderzoek zal gericht zijn op een concrete vraag van die opdrachtgever.

Onder begeleiding van de docenten worden alle noodzakelijke stappen ondernomen om het onderzoek op te zetten, uit te voeren en te rapporten. Essentieel is dat er in het onderzoek telkens gezocht wordt naar een combinatie van tekst- en beeld- en discoursanalyse enerzijds, en operationalisering voor empirisch onderzoek anderzijds. Daarnaast krijgen de studenten training in concrete onderzoeksvaardigheden: het formuleren van een wetenschappelijke onderzoeksvraag geënt op een maatschappelijke vraag; het kiezen van de juiste combinatie van onderzoeksmethoden; het analyseren van data, enzovoort..
Het CIW lab volg je in het verlengde van je verdiepingspakket:
LET OP: Wanneer je je inschrijft voor het CIW Lab kies je dan ook voor de groep die aansluit op het verdiepingspakket
1.         Digitale communicatie: Schrijf je in voor groep 2 óf groep 4  (thema Media en Cultuur)
2.         Media, communicatie en markt: Schrijf je in voor groep 2 óf groep 4 (thema Media en Cultuur)
3.         Communicatie, organisatie en interactie:Schrijf je in voor groep 1 óf groep 3 (thema Communicatie)
4.         Cultuur, communicatie en diversiteit: Schrijf je in voor groep 2 óf groep 4 (thema Media en Cultuur)
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175209,2016,Cultural and artistic didactics,Dutch,Graduate School of Teaching,,['drs. A.J. Westermann', 'M.P. Nagtzaam, MA']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afloop van de cursus heeft de student:
- inzicht in hoe (verschillend) het vak CKV wordt ingericht op verschillende scholen en welke keuzes daarbij doorslaggevend zijn;
- kennis van de domeinen van het examenprogramma CKV (Verkennen, Verbreden, Verdiepen en Verbinden) en doorloopt deze;

- een visiestuk geschreven waarin oa in wordt gegaan op de verschillende visies op kunst- en cultuureducatie; de invulling van CKV op de stageschool; het aanbod aan lesmateriaal en het belang van een ‘goede’ CKV-docent.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze keuzecursus staat de didactiek van het schoolvak Culturele en Kunstzinnige Vorming (CKV) centraal. Het doel is om kennis en inzichten te verwerven die je helpen verantwoorde en authentieke keuzes te maken in onderwijzen van het vak CKV.  Als CKV docent heb je namelijk een belangrijke taak: het is aan jou leerlingen te motiveren en enthousiasmeren en hen te begeleiden in het vormen van een nieuwsgierige attitude wat betreft het ervaren en waarderen van culturele en kunstzinnige uitingen. In deze cursus onderzoeken we wat het vak (in praktijk en theorie) inhoudt, waarom er een nieuw examenprogramma ingevoerd is, wat het van je vraagt om een goede CKV docent te zijn en welke rol ICT hierbij speelt.

De CRUX-toets is een kennisretentietoets, die als doel heeft om de basiskennis van studenten te versterken door eerder opgedane, klinisch relevante basiskennis uit de Bachelor Geneeskunde te herhalen.
De CRUX-toets bestaat uit vier deeltoetsen, CRUX-1, CRUX-2, CRUX-3 en CRUX-4. In iedere deeltoets zal stof uit 3 of 4 blokken worden herhaald. De inhoud van de CRUX-toetsen heeft betrekking op:

De CRUX-toets is onderdeel van de Bachelor Geneeskunde. In combinatie met de Utrechtse Voortgangstoets (UVT) in de Master Geneeskunde draagt de CRUX-toets bij aan een van de onderwijskundige kenmerken van CRU+: eenmaal verworven kennis blijft behouden gedurende de hele opleiding.

Per CRUX-toets zal een overzicht worden geboden van de onderwerpen/doelstellingen die aan bod komen. Verder geldt dezelfde literatuur voor de CRUX-toetsen als voor de blokken waarop de CRUX-toets betrekking heeft.
CRUX-toetsen zullen digitaal worden afgenomen en uitsluitend bestaan uit gesloten vragen. Per CRUX-toets zullen vier gelegenheden per jaar worden aangeboden waarop de toets gemaakt kan worden.
Voor iedere CRUX-toets afzonderlijk moet aan de volgende voorwaarden zijn voldaan:
-          De blokken waarop de CRUX-toets betrekking heeft moeten zijn doorlopen
-          De tentamens van de betreffende blokken moeten zijn gehaald

Aangezien de CRUX-toetsen niet van elkaar afhankelijk zijn is het behalen van een eerdere CRUX-toets geen voorwaarde voor het maken van de volgende CRUX-toets. De eerste mogelijkheid voor het maken van CRUX-1 is in september van Bachelor jaar 2. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: As members of the Netherlands Research School in Philosophy (OZSW) or the National Research School in Classical Studies (OIKOS), Research Master's students complete one seminar each year that is selected from a course list coordinated by the research schools. These are either (1) designated seminars offered by various Dutch universities (including Utrecht)  or (2) one of the research school's special offerings (e.g. the annual ""Autumn School"" for research master's students).(1) In the case of regularly offered courses, students register for the selected course at the host university (using that university's course code and title). The results for that course (including course title and grade) are then subsequently registered as Research School Seminar Year 1 (OFRM14001) or Research School Seminar Year 2 (OFRM14002).  (For more detailed instructions, contact the RMA Coordinator.) (2) In the case of special Research School offerings, credit and grades will be registered directly as Research School Seminar Year 1 (OFRM14001) or Research School Seminar Year 2 (OFRM14002), on the basis of a report provided to the RMA Coordinator by the coordinator of the research school event. Credits for the seminar varies, but the number of credits for the two Research School Seminars must add up to at least 10 ECTS.

Students who are abroad in their second year are advised to complete both courses during their first year. Information about available courses : http://www.ru.nl/oikos/research-master/ma-courses/ http://www.ozsw.nl/courses-seminars-for-research-master-students/ Useful instructions: http://www.ozsw.nl/exchange-between-dutch-universities/

column3: De onderzoeksmodule is deel  van het OST-traject. Het vindt plaats in periode 3 en is een ingangseis voor het mogen schrijven van de masterscriptie.  Zie de OER Master 2015-2016 voor nadere regels en Blackboard. Eerder in het academisch jaar moet worden doorgegeven binnen welk vakgebied de student wil afstuderen. Er zal daarover tijdig informatie worden verstrekt. Een scriptiebegeleider wordt toegewezen door de scriptiecoördinator van de master European Law middels een ingevuld scriptieformulier.

In de onderzoeksmodule dienen studenten naast een onderzoeksopzet, feedback te geven op opzet van andere studenten en een presentatie te geven over de eigen opzet. Aanwezigheid is verplicht. De onderzoeksmodule dient binnen drie weken te worden afgerond middels een goedgekeurde onderzoeksopzet.</body>

column2: • familiar with the breadth of topics covered in regional science, including those at its scientific frontier;
• able to see events in an evolutionary perspective;
• able to apply describe and understand pressing issues of sustainability, (urban) real estate and uneven growth, applying a healthy mixture of economic and geographic insights.

column1: The following aspects of academic research, reporting and effective oral presentation skills are covered in the course:

column2: • you learn to employ geographical-economical reasoning on a variety of new topics in a creative yet clear manner;
• you set up a research proposal combining different strands of literature;
• you are able to interpret the outcomes of a simplified geo-economic model;
• you are able to perform a hedonic pricing analysis.
• you effectively write out the findings of assignments.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Large differences exist in economic wealth and economic dynamics between countries and regions. Economic activities tend to concentrate in certain areas. We tackle this issue at several spatial levels and by adopting views from different disciplines. We start by looking at success and failure of countries and regions, and theories of convergence and divergence. We proceed with the famous Krugman “core-periphery” model, for which he won the Nobel prize in 2008. We then turn to the cutting edge field of evolutionary economics and its geographical applications. In particular, we take a geographical look at the position of the so-called third world in the current globalized world. Next, we consider an often undervalued branch of spatial economics, but one which has large implications for today´s urban world: that of real estate. A section on the role of the environment and sustainability in economics and geography completes the course. The course thus covers the current issues at the intersection of economics and geography, and it will feature a range of guest lectures by key specialists in their field.</body>

column4: Name course: Capita Selecta Medical Imaging – BMB502503
Prof.dr.ir. M.A. Viergever, Image Sciences Institute: coordinator assignments

Students will work on individual assignments under the supervision of a PhD-candidate, postdoc or senior researcher. At the end of the 10 week period the students have to hand in a report (max 2 A4-size) and they will give ten-minute presentations before an audience of fellow students and supervisors. The assignments will cover topics of ongoing research of the Image Sciences Institute and the Departments of Radiology and Radiotherapy of the Imaging Division of the University Medical Center Utrecht.
At least 2 weeks before start of the course (via email: bis@isi.uu.nl).

column3: Een Capita Selecta is een vak dat je op individuele basis doet bij een docent. Het kan gaan om een literatuurstudie, programmeerwerk, enz. Kortom: een project. Je moet als student zelf een onderwerp verzinnen en vervolgens een docent vinden die bereid is om zo'n Capita Selecta-vak te begeleiden. Het vak kan alleen met een omvang van 7,5 studiepunten gevolgd worden. Voor de bachelor fase kan het vak op niveau 1, 2 of 3 gevolgd worden. Let op: een bachelorstudent kan ten hoogste 1 project in het kader van Capita selecta in zijn programma opnemen, en wel in de profileringsruimte. Een masterstudent kan eveneens ten hoogste 1 project in het kader van Capita selecta in zijn programma opnemen, en behoeft daartoe de goedkeuring van de studieadviseur van zijn programma. De docent dient aan de start van het Capita Selecta-vak een formulier in te vullen en aan de studentenadministratie te verstrekken. Op dit formulier wordt aangegeven welk niveau het vak heeft, om hoeveel studiepunten het gaat, wat de taken van de student zijn, enz. Dit formulier is digitaal beschikbaar (in Word).</body>

column4: A Capita Selecta is a course that you can enroll in on an individual basis, in consultation with a staff member (lecturer, professor).

It could consist of a literature survey, a programming experiment, etc. In short: a project. As a student, you have to find a subject yourself, as well as a staff member who would like to supervise your project.
The course exists only in a 7,5 ECTS version.
Please note: a master program may contain a maximum of 1 Capita Selecta project per student. Furthermore, the approval of the graduate student adviser is required.

The staff member supervising the project must fill out a form to register the project with the student administration at the start of the project. On the form, the number of ECTS is indicated, as well as the tasks for the student and other relevant data about the project. The form is available on the website (in Word).

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179261,2016,Capita Selecta European Law: Big Data: Privacy & Competition,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student is able to understand and examine the data protection and competition law aspects of the collection and use of data by internet platforms.
• The student understand the interplay between these subfields of law.
• The student is able to analyze and evaluate regulatory developments in this field and take a position on the basis of relevant arguments.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Big technology companies such as Google and Facebook collect great amounts of data. These companies use these data to improve their services, for instance to produce personalized search results. But these data are also used to create profiles of users and to advertise more effectively.

Most of these data are ‘personal data’ to which data protection and privacy law applies. However, competition authorities have also shown an interest in regulating these companies, for these data have become critical to building successful internet platforms.

In this module we explore how privacy and competition law applies to the collection and use of these data, how these regimes may complement each other, but also where there is tension between the two.

In period 3 you will follow 3 modules to be chosen from a total of 9 modules on topics of European law. Period 3 is divided into 3 sub-periods of three weeks each. For each of the sub-periods you need to choose one module from the three modules offered in that sub-period. It is not possible to do more than one modules in the same sub-period. A fourth module, which is compulsory, regards the Research and Thesis Trajectory (RTT), and starts already in period 1. This module must be completed before starting the actual writing of the thesis in period 4. One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

The modules allow you to submerge yourself into a specific area of European Union law in a small-scale setting (max. 15 students). It is an intense form of education, aimed at deepening your knowledge in a specific field of EU law and at developing skills which will be important for your professional career. This means that none of the modules will be concluded by an exam. Instead, you will be tested in other ways. You might have to write a position paper, a case note, a weblog, a policy advice paper or you may be tested on the basis of a presentation or your input in a negotiating exercise.

If you fail one of the modules, you may not repair your grade within that module. Instead, a reparation module will be offered in period 4. The content and approach of that module will only be made public at the end of period 3. If you fail more than one module, you will have to take the Capita Selecta course the next year.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will gain knowledge of EU asylum law.
• Students will be able to critically assess the flaws and the advantages of the current legal framework of EU asylum law in light of the current pressures.
• Students will develop reasoned alternatives to the existing legal framework.
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The current migrant crisis has fundamentally challenged EU asylum policies. It had taken years to build the Common European Asylum System (CEAS), which is intended to ensure that the rights of refugees under international law are protected in its member states. The system sets out minimum standards and procedures for processing and assessing asylum applications, and for the treatment of asylum seekers. The migrant crisis has led the EU to adopt new measures. The EU-Turkey Migration Deal is aimed at addressing the overwhelming flow of smuggled migrants and asylum seekers traveling across the Aegean from Turkey to the Greek islands. The current system to decide which EU Member State is responsible for deciding on asylum requests – based on the Dublin Regulation – is under review as the migrant crisis has shown it to be highly ineffective.

Both measures have been subject to severe criticism. The aim of this module is, thus, to make proposals to improve these measures and to come to a better Asylum system in the EU. Such proposals need to reflect the ‘double balance’ which EU asylum law necessarily reflects: a balance between EU competence and national sovereignty and a balance between immigration control and human rights protection. Students are required to write position paper(s) proposing changes to the existing measures, following the first week of the module that is dedicated to deepening your knowledge on EU asylum law (i.a. via lectures). During the last week of the module, you will present and defend your proposals and discuss the proposals of your fellow students in expert meeting sessions. Your evaluation will be a combination of your position paper and your input in the expert meeting sessions.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

To which extent may national law regulate or affect the exercise of EU electoral rights? This is a question of great constitutional significance, as it not only touches upon the issue of competence but also upon the highly sensitive field of political rights. In this course, we will study this question on the basis of the Delvigne case (C-650/13). This case deals with a French national who decided to fight his exclusion, under French law, from the right to vote in elections to the European Parliament. Is Delvigne entitled to the protection of the Charter on Fundamental Rights of the EU in a situation like this? And what is the role of EU citizenship this respect? These are the central questions which we will seek to answer in this course.

The political rights of EU citizens and the EU Charter (in a broad context) will be debated in the lectures. In addition, the lectures will be followed by debate sessions, during which the students should be prepared to active discussion on a position linked to the political rights of EU citizens and the EU Charter. In the final week students should submit an essay on political EU citizenship, which they should present in a seminar.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will further develop the basic knowledge of the concepts of international law and EU law, which they have acquired in the General Course on Public International Law and EU law master courses
• They will familiarize themselves with basic international law on the characterisation and responsibility of international organisations
• Students will consider key questions surrounding the hierarchy of norms within the international and EU legal systems
• They will examine issues regarding the acquisition of binding international obligations by individual states and international organisations

• Students will consider more generally the evolution of international law and the EU, and critically engage with how practitioners, Member States, the CJEU and academics have constantly considered and re-considered the relationship between international law and the EU

• Students learn to distil and evaluate legal questions from existing normative debates and provide reasoned answers to them by employing persuasive analysis or arguments using analogical and deductive reasoning
• Students learn to critically approach and assess the legal questions posed
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Over the past decades, the European Union’s continued integration has given it a unique character as an international actor. While the EU characterises itself as a sui generis, autonomous and supranational legal order, this approach does not necessarily align with that of international law.

This module aims to discuss some key questions surrounding the interface between international law and the legal order of the European Union. In doing so, it seeks to uncover some inconsistencies between the international and EU approaches to the working of international law on both the EU and its member states. Interesting issues in this regard include EU competence to conclude international agreements such as Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership and the Kyoto Protocol, participation of the EU in international organisations such as the World Trade Organization, international responsibility, data protection in EU-US relations, and the hierarchy of international norms in the legal order of both the Union and its member states. The focus of the course is on questions of international trade and trade-related public policy measures.
This module is aimed at students with an interest in both public international and European law, and invites them to reflect critically on the EU’s growing role as a global actor. </body>

The students will be divided into small groups representing a Member State or an Institution. They will negotiate the withdrawal agreement mentioned in article 50 TEU following the Brexit referendum and the British Government’s intention to leave the European Union. For the purposes of this exercise, we assume that the United Kingdom has notified the European Council of its intention to leave the European Union. The participants will first write a position paper elaborating the position of the Member State or institution they represent (reflecting the interests of the Member State/institution concerned and based on legal argumentation). During the last week the actual negotiations exercise will take place.

An alternative way to take this module is for students who are participating in the oral rounds of the European Law moot court. They follow an intense training, focusing on their skills to present legal arguments and to improvise, by a team of Moot court trainers, followed by the actual oral rounds in a city in Europe or the US. They will be graded on the basis of their overall performance.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will consider the key question how EMU economic governance affects the division of authority between the EU and the Member States
• Students will examine this key question from a pre-defined perspective
• students will analyze EU legislation, doctrine, but most notably national and EU policy documents in light of the key question
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) is arguably one of the best-known and most important aspects of EU integration, but it has also become one of the most controversial ones. The economic crisis that erupted in 2008 revealed the flaws of the system. Since then, EMU law has undergone major changes and it has also been supplemented with a permanent bail out system for Member States, the Economic Stability Mechanism (ESM).

Economic coordination – unlike supranational monetary policy – is based on cooperation between EU institutions and national authorities. The European Semester is the yearly cycle of economic policy coordination that has been set up. In 2015, the European Commission decided to include more policy objectives. Objectives to pursue structural economic reforms and sound public finances have been supplemented with employment and social objectives and with democratic objectives.

The key question of this module is how the current system of economic policy coordination affects the division of authority between the European Union and the Member States? We will study the not only the procedural and institutional framework (e.g. the possibility for the EU to impose sanctions) but primarily assess the functioning of economic policy coordination in practice. The module is, thus, a combination of legal and political science/ public administration methods.  Students will be asked to adopt a perspective (e.g. of a Member State: Eurozone/non Eurozone/ESM; of a EU institution or of a substantive policy objective: social/institutional reform/democratic accountability etc.).

One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Have you heard about Europol, Frontex or the European Fisheries Control Agency? Did you know that there are 35 EU agencies and that agencies have become not only important decision-making but also supervisory entities at the EU level? For those who know little about and are simply interested in this relatively new but important development of EU law and governance, we are happy to offer our course! This course will advance the knowledge of the EU institutional law by exposing students to the issues of enforcement of EU law by EU agencies and their national counterparts. Also, it creates a good possibility to train professional skills, such as research, writing, critical evaluation and presentation. The course concludes by the creation of a joint blog presenting the results of all groups’ papers and their comparative analysis.
Background and key focus of the course:

Enforcing EU law has since recently become a task of an increasing number of EU institutions and agencies. As a result of the EU recent financial reform, the European Central Bank, for instance, directly supervises significant credit institutions, “representing almost 85% of total banking assets in the euro area.”[1] Together with the possibility to withdraw a bank authorization, its enforcement arsenal includes administrative sanctions. In addition, the financial reform has led to the creation of a number of independent financial supervisors, including the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). ESMA’s enforcement authority includes the powers to examine and take copies of any relevant records and materials, ask for oral explanations, summon and hear persons, require telephone and data traffic records, and interview persons. Such powers are not available even to the European Parliament in its investigatory capacity. Furthermore, Frontex, a European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union, has recently turned into an agency with own operational enforcement capacity. Following its modified founding regulation (amended by Regulation 1168/2011), the agency has finalized a tender to buy aerial surveillance to be used in joint operations[2] (instead of relying on the equipment of the EU Member States). The border guards are not anymore only those of Member States. The so-called Seconded Guest Officers (SGO) are employed by Frontex for up to six months per officer. The officers wear their own national uniform, but wear a blue Frontex and EU armband when deployed. The list of examples could continue but the point is clear: the EU has been acquiring direct enforcement power (i.e., monitoring, investigation and punishment in relation to individuals and companies, not only in relation to the EU Member States).

At the same time, while EU institutions and agencies have acquired direct supervisory powers, the exercise of those powers can be dependent on or shared with national level authorities (supervising institutions and courts). For instance, when ESMA needs to examine and to take copies of any relevant records and materials of a credit rating agency hosted in London, it has to obtain first an authorization of an English judge.[3] What if an English judge refuses to give such an authorization? Will ESMA render account for not doing her job or should the judge be accountable? By whom/at what level would they render accountability?

Since the trend of empowering EU entities with direct enforcement powers is quite recent, little is known about how shared enforcement is organized between EU and national authorities. What does an EU entity (institution, agency) and a national supervising authority do exactly when they enforce EU law? Are their tasks divided/subordinated to each other or do they share enforcement tasks? How and at what level do they render (political, judicial) accountability for the enforcement tasks? We invite students to explore these questions in the cases of their choice (an EU agency – one or more national counterparts of any EU Member State).

Having followed this course, students will advance their knowledge of the EU institutional law in three respects. Firstly, EU law is usually studied from a regulatory perspective (e.g., how regulations and directives are being made, in according with what procedures, on what topics, etc.). This is because the Treaties have been giving predominately regulatory tasks to the EU institutions. In this course, the focus is on the next stage of the EU policy cycle, namely enforcement: how do EU and national authorities make sure that EU law is complied with by individuals and private parties? How can the respective authorities investigate suspicious cases and punish for non-compliance? Secondly, EU law courses focus usually on the main EU institutions. EU agencies, which are hardly regulated by the Treaties, are normally discussed very briefly, if at all. In this course, students will be introduced to the EU agency phenomenon, which has become an important part of EU governance. The number of EU agencies has been proliferating in the recent years considerably (from approximately 10 to 35 in the last 15 years!). And their powers have become to include not only information-gathering but also decision-making and supervision. It is therefore important to get familiar with these new important actors at the EU policy making and implementing level. Thirdly, during this course a number of important skills for EU legal professionals will be trained: research, writing, critical evaluation and presentation skills. All in all, this course is a valuable supplement to the courses of the EU law master programme and possibly other interested students. It aims to complete the knowledge on the EU institutional law by focusing on the novel questions and challenges with which EU law and governance have been dealing within and outside the Treaties’ borders.

Students are offered to participate in interactive lectures, which will be based on academic and officials materials announced before the lecture. Lectures will be followed by debates in the form of seminars where more specific problems and challenges to shared enforcement will be discussed. Furthermore, students will be invited to form groups for their writing assignments and presentations. Groups of students will be given the chance to improve their paper after having submitted a first draft. The teaching staff and other groups will give their comments on written drafts and presentations. Depending on the number of participants, this course will be concluded by creating one/more blogs on the main topic, including the results of all group investigations.
[1] This information is taken from the official webpage of the ECB. Find at:  http://www.ecb.europa.eu/ssm/html/index.en.html.

[2] Annual Information on the Commitments of the Member States to the European Border Guard Teams and the Technical Equipment Pool, Report 2014. Available at: http://www.statewatch.org/news/2014/mar/eu-frontex-rep-ep-msd.pdf  (last check June 2015), pp. 7, 12.
[3] See the recent case at http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Ch/2015/1085.html

In period 3 you will follow 3 modules to be chosen from a total of 9 modules on topics of European law. Period 3 is divided into 3 sub-periods of three weeks each. For each of the sub-periods you need to choose one module from the three modules offered in that sub-period. It is not possible to do more than one modules in the same sub-period. A fourth module, which is compulsory, regards the Research and Thesis Trajectory (RTT), and starts already in period 1. This module must be completed before starting the actual writing of the thesis in period 4. One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

The modules allow you to submerge yourself into a specific area of European Union law in a small-scale setting (max. 15 students). It is an intense form of education, aimed at deepening your knowledge in a specific field of EU law and at developing skills which will be important for your professional career. This means that none of the modules will be concluded by an exam. Instead, you will be tested in other ways. You might have to write a position paper, a case note, a weblog, a policy advice paper or you may be tested on the basis of a presentation or your input in a negotiating exercise.

If you fail one of the modules, you may not repair your grade within that module. Instead, a reparation module will be offered in period 4. The content and approach of that module will only be made public at the end of period 3. If you fail more than one module, you will have to take the Capita Selecta course the next year.

At the end of the course students:

column2: • Will have insight in the historical development of EU gender and non-discrimination law
• Will have insight in key concepts in EU non-discrimination law as codified in diverse EU directives and interpreted by the Court of Justice of the EU
• Wll be able to critically assess these developments and conceptualisation of the principle of equality from diverse perspectives
• will have insight in a few national law systems of EU member states in relation to gender equality and non-discrimination law.

column1: At the end of the course students:

column2: • Will be able to assimilate knowledge on a complicated field of law in a short period of time
• Will be able to assess critically the relevant existing EU law and express their findings in plenary discussions
• Will learn how to find reliable information on relevant national law
• Will be able to give short oral presentations in English
• Will be able to develop their own opinion on diverse issues at stake and present it in plenaries during the course and to a broad audience at the end of the course.
• Will develop their written skills in English by writing a paper
• Will be able to give and receive feedback on their (draft) paper

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

EU equality and non-discrimination law has developed since 1957 and consists now of an extensive body of law which has a great impact on national law of the Member States. EU equality law offers diverse tools to combat discrimination on the ground of sex/gender, race and ethnicity, religion and belief, sexual orientation, disability and age. The case law of the Court of Justice of the EU on sex/gender equality is particularly interesting, as some key concepts and approaches that have been developed in this area apply also to other fields of law and legal doctrine thereon is extensive. The focus during this course is therefore on sex/gender equality law.

The Court of Justice has developed key concepts such as the concept of indirect discrimination, which allows to bring more hidden forms of discrimination within the scope of EU law. It had also to consider in which cases direct sex discrimination is at stake and prohibited. Is an employer for example required to pay a Christmas bonus to women who have been absent during a few months due to pregnancy and maternity leave? Is an employer allowed to refuse the renewal of a fixed-term contract in case of pregnancy? Is positive action for women at universities allowed, even if this means that male candidates which fulfil the requirements cannot apply for certain functions? In how far is pay transparency required in order to combat gender pay gaps?
Improving a better gender balance in company boards is now one of the priorities of the European Commission. In addition, improved work life balance rights are on the agenda of the EU.

These are examples of issues that will be addressed in this learning by doing course. Discussions between lecturers and students will be at the core of the seminars. The course aims at enhancing students’ academic competences by encouraging critical assessments of existing law from different perspectives. The course will start in the first week with the study and assessment of the analytical and conceptual framework of EU gender equality law and its historical development. Attention will be paid to the notions of formal, substantive and transformative gender equality and how these may determine our assessment and appreciation of existing equality laws. The impact of EU gender equality law at the national level will be central during the second week of the course. Students will give oral presentations, preside and participate in debates in the class, defend statements and develop their own opinions, based on the analysis of case law of different national jurisdictions. In the third week, students will write a paper, give and receive feedback on their paper and present their work to a broader audience at the end of the course. The evaluation will be based on the participation in the seminars, oral presentations and the paper.

column2: • Students will further develop the basic knowledge of the concepts of international law and EU law, which they have acquired in the General Course on Public International Law and EU law master courses
• They will familiarize themselves with basic international law on the characterisation and responsibility of international organisations
• Students will consider key questions surrounding the hierarchy of norms within the international and EU legal systems
• They will examine issues regarding the acquisition of binding international obligations by individual states and international organisations

• Students will consider more generally the evolution of international law and the EU, and critically engage with how practitioners, Member States, the CJEU and academics have constantly considered and re-considered the relationship between international law and the EU

• Students learn to distil and evaluate legal questions from existing normative debates and provide reasoned answers to them by employing persuasive analysis or arguments using analogical and deductive reasoning
• Students learn to critically approach and assess the legal questions posed
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Equality between men and women is one of the core values of the European Union. However, across the EU women are underrepresented in decision-making positions in politics and business. In November 2012, the Commission published a proposal for a Directive on improving the gender balance among non-executive directors of companies listed on stock exchanges (COM(2012) 614 final). The purpose of this proposal is to “substantially increase the number of women on corporate boards throughout the EU by setting a minimum objective of a 40% presence of the under-represented sex among the non-executive directors of companies listed on stock exchanges and by requiring companies with a lower share of the underrepresented sex among the non-executive directors to introduce pre-established, clear, neutrally formulated and unambiguous criteria in selection procedures for those positions in order to attain that objective” (p. 5 of the Explanatory Memorandum). Thus, the aim of this new legislation is to accelerate progress towards a better gender balance on the corporate boards of European companies. At the same time, numerous EU Member States have initiated national legislation or other measures in the field. National approaches vary from legislative to self- and co-regulatory ones. In this course module we will look at these measures to improve the gender balance in company boards. After an introduction of the European regulatory framework, we will study a few of the national approaches and compare these with the EU approach on this issue. Each student will be asked to study this theme from a different perspective in a paper. We shall then have joint sessions in which a debate can take place. The grade shall be given on the basis of the paper.
